text: Given: tangent PT touches circle at P. O is center. Show OP ⟂ PT.
answer:
Step 1: Join OP. Suppose OP not perpendicular.
Step 2: Draw radius OQ ⟂ PT at Q. Then Q is point of contact.
Step 3: But tangent touches circle at only one point. Contradiction.
Step 4: Hence OP ⟂ PT.

text: Circle with center O, radius 5 cm. A tangent PT is drawn from external point T. If OT = 13 cm, find PT.
answer:
Step 1: △OPT is right triangle with OP=5, OT=13.
Step 2: PT²=OT²−OP²=169−25=144.
Step 3: PT=√144=12 cm.

Step 2: PT²=OT²−OP²=625−49=576.
Step 3: PT=√576=24 cm.

text: From point A outside circle with center O, two tangents AP, AQ are drawn. If OA=13 cm, radius=5 cm, find length of AP and AQ.

Step 2: AP²=13²−5²=169−25=144.
Step 3: AP=√144=12. AQ=12 (equal).

text: Prove tangents drawn from an external point to a circle are equal in length.
answer:
Step 1: Let O be circle center, A external point. Draw tangents AP, AQ touching at P, Q.
Step 2: Join OP, OQ, OA.
Step 3: △OPA and △OQA are right triangles with common hypotenuse OA.
Step 4: OP=OQ (radii), OA common, ∠OPA=∠OQA=90°.
Step 5: By congruence, AP=AQ. Hence lengths are equal.

text: Circle center O, tangent PT touches at P. Radius OP=5, OT=13. Find PT and prove △OPT right-angled at P.
answer:
Step 1: △OPT has OP=5, OT=13.
Step 2: PT²=OT²−OP²=169−25=144.
Step 3: PT=12.
Step 4: Since OP²+PT²=5²+12²=25+144=169=OT², △OPT is right at P.

Step 2: PT²=25²−7²=625−49=576.
Step 3: PT=24 cm.
Step 4: Since OP²+PT²=7²+24²=49+576=625=OT², right-angled at P.
